title: Practice Challenge
description: Apply what you've learned in this interactive coding challenge.
instructions:
Understand the limitations of file-based storage!

1. Create a 'Product' class (Id, Name, Price)

2. Create a list of 5 products

3. Simulate file storage:
   - 'Save' products by printing each as CSV line
   - Print: \"Saving to file: [Id],[Name],[Price]\"

4. Simulate file search:
   - To find product by ID, print \"Reading entire file...\"
   - Loop through ALL products to find match
   - Print how many products were checked

5. Explain the problems:
   - Print why this is slow for 1 million products
   - Print why concurrent writes are dangerous
   - Print what databases solve

This demonstrates WHY we need databases!

hints.text: Loop through products to save. Loop through again to search (simulate reading file). Count how many checked. Print problems: speed, scale, corruption, relationships.
Thinking files are fine: For simple config or logs, files are OK! But for application DATA (users, products, orders), files are terrible. Always use database for data!
Not understanding indexes: Files have no indexes - must read everything! Databases create indexes on columns (like book index). Find \"Smith\" in millions of names = instant!
Ignoring concurrency: Single-user app? Files might work. Multi-user? Files = disaster. Databases handle thousands of concurrent users safely with locking/transactions.
Missing transactions: If app crashes mid-write to file, file is corrupted! Databases use transactions: changes are all-or-nothing (atomic). Crash? Database rolls back, stays consistent!
